subject: RE: [junit] Please Help, Need Guidance
msgSnippet: Hi Mikhail, You can have a look at Cactus (http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus). It it based on top of JUnit and it will help you for unit testing Servlets, EJBs,
messageBody:
Hi Mikhail,

You can have a look at Cactus (http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus). It it
based on top of JUnit and it will help you for unit testing Servlets,
EJBs, Taglibs, Filters (MDBs not yet but coming soon ;-)). It won't help
you more than pure JUnit for XML processing though.

You may also want to have a look at Mock Objects (see
http://www.mockobjects.com).

Good luck,
-Vincent

> -----Original Message-----
> From: mschnayd [mailto:mschnayd@...]
> Sent: 22 February 2002 20:36
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Please Help, Need Guidance
>
> Hello Guys,
>
> I am an architect for a small software company. We have been
> developing our product for about two years now, and have been trying
> to be pretty good about the developmental practices. We have coding
> standards, good architecture and frameworks in place, and allot of
> tallented developers. What we don't have is a solid suite of unit
> tests.
>
> What happened is at the beginning of the project management was
> onboard with the schedule that we demanded that included time for
> building the unit tests. For about 6 month now that is no longer a
> case. We have not written unit tests for the past 6 month. The
> tests that have been written are long out of sync. with the codebase,
> to the point where everyone has them excluded from compilation.
>
> I really would like us to get back on track and developer a better
> quality product; alos, god knows our QA need some help.
>
> Anyway, to keep a long story short, what I am looking for is for best
> practices and guidlines on developintg unit tests for various types
> of classes (Regular classes, Servlets, EJBs, MDBs, XML processing).
> Is there a framework that somebody has developed on top of the JUnit.
> If not, I would be glad to build one, assuming it will not require
> too much time. Being a great fan of reuse, I would rather use an
> already created testing framework. JUnit is great, but it is very
> simple and does not have guidance on testing Data Access code, ...
>
> If any of you can give me a list of books, articles, code samples,
> references to other web-sites; I will greatly appreciate it.
> I am realy glad that people like Erich Gamma and Kent Beck are out
> there to help the rest of us get our acts together; however, there is
> still some much more that could be done to make life easier for
> fast-pased development teams like the one I am working for.
>
> Regards, Mikhail Shnayderman.
